user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_uint64_to_str:
```c
size_t
MHD_uint64_to_str (uint64_t val,
                   char *buf,
                   size_t buf_size)
{
  char *chr;  /**< pointer to the current printed digit */
  /* The biggest printable number is 18446744073709551615 */
  uint64_t divisor = UINT64_C (10000000000000000000);
  int digit;

  chr = buf;
  digit = (int) (val / divisor);
  mhd_assert (digit < 10);

  /* Do not print leading zeros */
  while ((0 == digit) && (1 < divisor))
  {
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }

  while (0 != buf_size)
  {
    *chr = (char) ((char) digit + '0');
    chr++;
    buf_size--;
    if (1 == divisor)
      return (size_t) (chr - buf);
    val %= divisor;
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }
  return 0; /* The buffer is too small */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected the function body and found no calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.). There are no indirect calls or function pointers invoking standard string routines, and no inclusion/usage of string.h functions in this fragment. Therefore there are no code fragments relevant to Rule 21.17 to investigate.

Notes (not relevant to Rule 21.17 but informative):
- The code does perform direct writes via the pointer 'chr' (derived from the parameter 'buf'). Those writes could overflow the caller-provided buffer if buf is NULL or buf_size does not reflect the actual buffer length; this is a general buffer-safety concern but is outside the scope of MISRA Rule 21.17, which specifically targets the use of <string.h> functions.
- Other operations (division, modulus, mhd_assert calls, decrementing buf_size) do not involve <string.h> functions and therefore are not subject to Rule 21.17 checks.
